On 02/06/2006 03:23 PM, Cédric Beust ♔ apparently said:
> On 2/6/06, Jason Rogers <jacaetevha@...> wrote:
> >
> >
> >
> > You can use Type Inference.
>
>
> Not when you don't have any types :-)

True, but my mind was (silently?) focused on dynamic languages like 
Smalltalk and Ruby.

>
> When Type Inference yields ambiguous
> > responses the tool ought to make you aware of it and give you the
> > opportunity to cancel or make a logical choice between the inferred
> > types.
>
>
> Yup. But think about the pain of renaming 100 methods throughout your
> project and having to click on "Yes" or "No" for every single one of 
> them...
>

True, but the UI is not at issue (and it could be dealt with easily, in 
various ways). What is at issue is whether or not it's impossible and 
whether or not it's string-based. No, it isn't impossible. No, it isn't 
string based. :)

-- 
Jason Rogers
